EDITORIAL COMMENT
BROTHER BABBITT
1MRATERNITIES are causing the American colleges-to turn gradually from the advancement of book learning .to the training of
practical business men. Universities were formerly dedicated to critical analysis, logical reasoning, aesthetic appreciation and ethical paination. Now veith the dominating influence of the Greek letter,'chapters over the members of the student body, our colleges are beginning'.
to instill into our American youth such moral qualities as the fighting
spirit, the will-to-win and initiative.
Such is the interesting theory advanced by Max McConn, Dean
of Lehigh University, in the current issue of The North American
Review._ At the beginning of his treatise, the author reveals the informition that the Average college fraternity takes into account four
principal points in the rushing of freshmen: money; familY; the preparatory school which the rushee attended; and personal qualities.
The financial standing of the candidate is of little importance to
the fraternity rushing committee. If the freshman's father is an influential man in his home town and the frosh's mother is a social
leader, the rushee's chances of receiving a bid are materially increased.
The social reputation of the preparatory school which he attended is
also considered of great importance by the fraternity.
But of the four criteria, the matter of "personality" stands foremost. A boy with a winning smile, a "smooth line" of conversation
and a pleasing manner, is certain to be taken. If he has won dis- •
tinction in athletics, dramatics or college publication work he be•
_
comes even more desirable. - •
Fraternities seem to put little or no emphasis on the matter of
scholastic perfection, in the opinion of the Lehigh educator. The
chapter is, of course, interested to the extent of seeing to it that its
members "stay in college".. Probation for a, member means that he
will be debarred from athletic competition and participation in!outside activities. The typical fraternity house is distinctly non-intellectual in general atmosphere and any conversation of a "high brow"
nature is completely taboo.
But the author hastens to explain that he.is not attempting anything in the nature of an "indictment" of the fraternity. He admits
that the typical Greek fritter is an exceedingly_inaustrious and hard
working young man. In addition to his periods of class room work
and studies, he must play on the teams, practice .for the glee club,
attend dramatic rehearsals, organize meetings, give dances, arrange
banquets and sit on numberless boards and committees.. Students contend that these outside activities are a more valuable means of training than book learning. When they graduate, they send their sons
back to the campus to follow in their footsteps and become student
leaders. Dr. McConn makes no attempt to refute these claims—on
the contrary, he admits that these contenions are sound and correct.
These students, with their self-devised course of training, consisting of outside activities, stand for a conception of higher education, quite different from the traditional idea. In the last forty years,
states the author, a new type of student has entered the American
universities—a student who is incapable of profiting by the old method
of book learning. Sponsored by the college fraternity„ he is obtaining
his education through work on the student activities. A campus Babbitt, so to speak.
Dr. McConn'a-discussion revolves about the old, old question of
the relative value of student activities as opposed to academic work.
He pictures the fraternities as pushing the student one way, while the
orthodox college professor is pulling him in another direction.
It has long been our opinion that in this new world of high pre&
sure business methods and rapid fire commercial activity, the apprenticeship served on the editorial staff of a college publication, or in,
some other campus activity, is a valuable preparation for the struggle
for existence after graduation. But'no one can deny the cultural and
aesthetic value of academic work and book learning. Again, we enter
our plea for a sensible balance of these two important phases of college life.

On the wall of a room in the
Memorial Hall there hangs a poem
by Margaret Johnston Graftlin
which the editor of this column believes is worth your attention.

The first novel of our own Dr.
Boas is not, we regret to predict,
destined to be the long awaitea
epic of American college faculty
life. For that it is too sketchy,
its length insufficient, its characters too few, the attention given
to yctra-collegiate _events_ too
great.
But it is—and this 'may be
more important—very delightful
reading-for'Ode who has had experience with college faculties,
and who is therefore anxious to
look behind the scenes of their
academic existence. This view
the author, with quite shameless
candor and quite biting sarcasm,
proceeds to give.
Francis Harper, who is the author himself without doubt, is ,
called to Oralia University, in
California, as an instructor in
English. 4'here, as a witty but
not brilliant man of ready sallies
and few ideas, Harper is well received by his,fellow instructors,
invited to their teas, their musicales, and their bickerings, all of
which are, of course, very informal.
With his characters in these
easy attitudes, Dr. Boas begins
with masterful strokes of satire
and really good bits of dialogue
to expose their souls. Here the
author reaches his greatest
heights, for character portrayal,
as those who have taken his
courses here know, is his true
forte, as the satirical is his most
fluent farm of discourse. Calmly,
relentlessly as a surgeon, the author dissects Harper and his
friends, shows the. reader what
manner of men'they afF,-changes
some, sekvs -them tip again, and
sets them to work as they will.

EDITORIAL COMMENT
BROTHER BABBITT
1MRATERNITIES are causing the American colleges-to turn gradually from the advancement of book learning .to the training of
practical business men. Universities were formerly dedicated to critical analysis, logical reasoning, aesthetic appreciation and ethical paination. Now veith the dominating influence of the Greek letter,'chapters over the members of the student body, our colleges are beginning'.
to instill into our American youth such moral qualities as the fighting
spirit, the will-to-win and initiative.
Such is the interesting theory advanced by Max McConn, Dean
of Lehigh University, in the current issue of The North American
Review._ At the beginning of his treatise, the author reveals the informition that the Average college fraternity takes into account four
principal points in the rushing of freshmen: money; familY; the preparatory school which the rushee attended; and personal qualities.
The financial standing of the candidate is of little importance to
the fraternity rushing committee. If the freshman's father is an influential man in his home town and the frosh's mother is a social
leader, the rushee's chances of receiving a bid are materially increased.
The social reputation of the preparatory school which he attended is
also considered of great importance by the fraternity.
But of the four criteria, the matter of "personality" stands foremost. A boy with a winning smile, a "smooth line" of conversation
and a pleasing manner, is certain to be taken. If he has won dis- •
tinction in athletics, dramatics or college publication work he be•
_
comes even more desirable. - •
Fraternities seem to put little or no emphasis on the matter of
scholastic perfection, in the opinion of the Lehigh educator. The
chapter is, of course, interested to the extent of seeing to it that its
members "stay in college".. Probation for a, member means that he
will be debarred from athletic competition and participation in!outside activities. The typical fraternity house is distinctly non-intellectual in general atmosphere and any conversation of a "high brow"
nature is completely taboo.
But the author hastens to explain that he.is not attempting anything in the nature of an "indictment" of the fraternity. He admits
that the typical Greek fritter is an exceedingly_inaustrious and hard
working young man. In addition to his periods of class room work
and studies, he must play on the teams, practice .for the glee club,
attend dramatic rehearsals, organize meetings, give dances, arrange
banquets and sit on numberless boards and committees.. Students contend that these outside activities are a more valuable means of training than book learning. When they graduate, they send their sons
back to the campus to follow in their footsteps and become student
leaders. Dr. McConn makes no attempt to refute these claims—on
the contrary, he admits that these contenions are sound and correct.
These students, with their self-devised course of training, consisting of outside activities, stand for a conception of higher education, quite different from the traditional idea. In the last forty years,
states the author, a new type of student has entered the American
universities—a student who is incapable of profiting by the old method
of book learning. Sponsored by the college fraternity„ he is obtaining
his education through work on the student activities. A campus Babbitt, so to speak.
Dr. McConn'a-discussion revolves about the old, old question of
the relative value of student activities as opposed to academic work.
He pictures the fraternities as pushing the student one way, while the
orthodox college professor is pulling him in another direction.
It has long been our opinion that in this new world of high pre&
sure business methods and rapid fire commercial activity, the apprenticeship served on the editorial staff of a college publication, or in,
some other campus activity, is a valuable preparation for the struggle
for existence after graduation. But'no one can deny the cultural and
aesthetic value of academic work and book learning. Again, we enter
our plea for a sensible balance of these two important phases of college life.

On the wall of a room in the
Memorial Hall there hangs a poem
by Margaret Johnston Graftlin
which the editor of this column believes is worth your attention.

The first novel of our own Dr.
Boas is not, we regret to predict,
destined to be the long awaitea
epic of American college faculty
life. For that it is too sketchy,
its length insufficient, its characters too few, the attention given
to yctra-collegiate _events_ too
great.
But it is—and this 'may be
more important—very delightful
reading-for'Ode who has had experience with college faculties,
and who is therefore anxious to
look behind the scenes of their
academic existence. This view
the author, with quite shameless
candor and quite biting sarcasm,
proceeds to give.
Francis Harper, who is the author himself without doubt, is ,
called to Oralia University, in
California, as an instructor in
English. 4'here, as a witty but
not brilliant man of ready sallies
and few ideas, Harper is well received by his,fellow instructors,
invited to their teas, their musicales, and their bickerings, all of
which are, of course, very informal.
With his characters in these
easy attitudes, Dr. Boas begins
with masterful strokes of satire
and really good bits of dialogue
to expose their souls. Here the
author reaches his greatest
heights, for character portrayal,
as those who have taken his
courses here know, is his true
forte, as the satirical is his most
fluent farm of discourse. Calmly,
relentlessly as a surgeon, the author dissects Harper and his
friends, shows the. reader what
manner of men'they afF,-changes
some, sekvs -them tip again, and
sets them to work as they will.
